title: What is the back light on a TV? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most TV’s today are based on LCD (Liquid Crystal Display) Screens. LCD’s are great at producing an image, but they do not emit any light. In order for them to display an image there must be a light source behind the LCD, a “backlight”. The LCD then selectively blocks or allows light through to create the image. Backlights for many years were CCFL (cold-cathode fluorescent light), but now are typically LED’s (Light Emitting Diodes). LED’s can either be used “edge-lit” with several along the edge of the screen, or in an array with many LED’s placed behind the LCD panel.
I set it to a medium setting. If it’s a bright day I set it to high. Sometimes at night I set it to low.
